description: A clinical condition, problem, diagnosis, or other event, situation, issue, or clinical concept that has risen to a level of concern.

properties.name: Condition
properties.short: Detailed information about conditions, problems or diagnoses
properties.definition: A clinical condition, problem, diagnosis, or other event, situation, issue, or clinical concept that has risen to a level of concern.

properties.name: id
properties.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
properties.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

properties.name: meta
properties.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

properties.name: implicitRules
properties.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
properties.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
properties.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

properties.name: language
properties.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
properties.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

properties.name: text
properties.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
properties.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
properties.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

properties.name: contained
properties.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
properties.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

properties.name: identifier
properties.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this condition by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
properties.comment: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](resource.html#identifiers)).  It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types.  For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

properties.name: clinicalStatus
properties.short: active | recurrence | relapse | inactive | remission | resolved
properties.definition: The clinical status of the condition.
properties.comment: The data type is CodeableConcept because clinicalStatus has some clinical judgment involved, such that there might need to be more specificity than the required FHIR value set allows. For example, a SNOMED coding might allow for additional specificity.

properties.name: verificationStatus
properties.short: unconfirmed | provisional | differential | confirmed | refuted | entered-in-error
properties.definition: The verification status to support the clinical status of the condition.
properties.comment:
verificationStatus is not required.  For example, when a patient has abdominal pain in the ED, there is not likely going to be a verification status.
The data type is CodeableConcept because verificationStatus has some clinical judgment involved, such that there might need to be more specificity than the required FHIR value set allows. For example, a SNOMED coding might allow for additional specificity.

properties.name: category
properties.definition: A category assigned to the condition.
properties.comment: The categorization is often highly contextual and may appear poorly differentiated or not very useful in other contexts.

properties.name: severity
properties.definition: A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.
properties.comment: Coding of the severity with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

properties.name: code
properties.short: Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis
properties.definition: Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis.

properties.name: bodySite
properties.definition: The anatomical location where this condition manifests itself.
properties.comment: Only used if not implicit in code found in Condition.code. If the use case requires attributes from the BodySite resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension [bodySite](extension-bodysite.html).  May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both.

properties.name: subject
properties.definition: Indicates the patient or group who the condition record is associated with.

properties.name: encounter
properties.definition: The Encounter during which this Condition was created or to which the creation of this record is tightly associated.
properties.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some activities may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter. This record indicates the encounter this particular record is associated with.  In the case of a "new" diagnosis reflecting ongoing/revised information about the condition, this might be distinct from the first encounter in which the underlying condition was first "known".

properties.name: onset[x]
properties.short: Estimated or actual date,  date-time, or age
properties.definition: Estimated or actual date or date-time  the condition began, in the opinion of the clinician.
properties.comment: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition began to occur.

properties.name: abatement[x]
properties.definition: The date or estimated date that the condition resolved or went into remission. This is called "abatement" because of the many overloaded connotations associated with "remission" or "resolution" - Conditions are never really resolved, but they can abate.
properties.comment: There is no explicit distinction between resolution and remission because in many cases the distinction is not clear. Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition abated.  If there is no abatement element, it is unknown whether the condition has resolved or entered remission; applications and users should generally assume that the condition is still valid.  When abatementString exists, it implies the condition is abated.

properties.name: recordedDate
properties.definition: The recordedDate represents when this particular Condition record was created in the system, which is often a system-generated date.

properties.name: recorder
properties.definition: Individual who recorded the record and takes responsibility for its content.

properties.name: asserter
properties.definition: Individual who is making the condition statement.

properties.name: stage
properties.definition: Clinical stage or grade of a condition. May include formal severity assessments.

properties.name: summary
properties.definition: A simple summary of the stage such as "Stage 3". The determination of the stage is disease-specific.

properties.name: assessment
properties.definition: Reference to a formal record of the evidence on which the staging assessment is based.

properties.name: type
properties.definition: The kind of staging, such as pathological or clinical staging.

properties.name: evidence
properties.definition: Supporting evidence / manifestations that are the basis of the Condition's verification status, such as evidence that confirmed or refuted the condition.
properties.comment: The evidence may be a simple list of coded symptoms/manifestations, or references to observations or formal assessments, or both.
